reviews.review_msg: A "language processing in Prolog" class much more than it is an AI class.  Doesn't explain things well in lecture and the overall "flow" of the course seems disorganized.  I recommend seeing her outside of class or sending e-mails, she's very helpful and thorough there.  Overall, not as bad as some of the reviews here suggest, but not great either.

First of all she is so mean, and she has such a cheap character! Second, she does not understand that she's teaching undergrad not some grad students w/ tons of AI background! Exams do not make sense and they are so abstract. She is so unorganized. DO NOT TAKE THIS COURSE W/ HER!

Do not take this course with her if you are actually interested in AI.  She is very knowledgeable in AI but her teaching abilities are terrible and she is not friendly to students.  A terrible prof. and not a nice person.

She is very knowledgeable, but a bit disorganized with her lectures. it is better if you know prolog pretty well before you take the class otherwise be prepare to master it. Her marking is pretty tough for the exams and midterms so study hard for them and you can easily get an A in the course. I would recomend taking her class!!

The absolute worst prof at SFU. Not helpful and mean to students. If you ask her to clarify on a point made during lecture she will glare at you and accuse you of not paying attention in class. During class she threatens to fail half the students then indulges herself by boasting about the things that she has done with her life.

This was the worst teacher I have ever had.  This was suppose to be an AI course but instead she made it into a course on the only thing she knows (Prolog).  The only problems is she doesn't know how to teach that either.  Rearranges the syllabus.

She never seemed prepared to teach. Made the class up as she went along. Changed the date of the final exam half way through the course which threw everyone. I felt like I didn't learn anything in the course and was glad when it ended.
A bit flakey
No midterm = no idea what final will be like.  Lectures didn't prepare us well for assignments.  Moved final 2 weeks earlier "for our benefit".
No Comments
No Comments
atrocious speaking/teaching abilities, arrogant, multiple complaints filed

Milan in Spring 2023 was not prepared to teach this course. Material covered was tangential at best and did not touch on core concepts/algorithms. He taught similarly to CMPT 105W in Fall 2021. Tofiloski was replaced by Harinder Khangura for the remaining half of the course. Great for a free grade, not so much for an educational experience.
Promised interesting practical projects, but man forgot about them and released only 10% of the planned coursework within half of the semester before getting replaced

Honestly Milan is great! 
I have learned a lot until now even though we did not have full 3 hrs boring lectures compare to other classes, we had some amazing discussion with my group, and I got familiar with Unity environment which is much better than bunch of random quizzes.
He doesn't know what the course is supposed to be. The lectures are about his random thoughts not related to the syllabus. Take Milan if you want an easy A.

Milan is a professor who obviously does not want to lecture. His lecturing style involves speaking sweet nothings about the most broad topics he can think of. His idea of a 3 hour lecture block is spending an hour on an in class discussion, then lecturing for another 20-30 minutes, then ending. 

I thought I was paying for 3 hours of lecture...
Nice guy, but doesn't know AI. The course was a complete joke. I got A, but didn't learn anything. I want my money back.
Great professor. Do not understand where those negative reviews come from. Everything was fair in my opinion. He's a legend.

Milan is nice. But the course content was so useless, that if you've ever watched a YouTube video on AI, you pretty much learn everything that's taught in this class. The course was also super disorganized. We had no idea what we were learning, or why. Nothing practical either. The assignments were extremely rushed, time consuming and confusing.

Honestly not as bad of a professor as people made him out to be. His lecture is kinda useless but he do post very concise videos that you can watch instead. His quizzes are very hard but they usually don't worth much. The projects are actually quite fun after you get the hang of it and they have a lot of real life applicability.

Indisputably one of the worst prof at SFU. He does not teach anything in class, rather he assigns a ton of assignments and you will be on your own to learn the class material yourself. The assignments are tedious and difficult, especially since the students lack the knowledge to complete them due to lack of teaching. 100% avoid him.

The man does not teach, and assignments are insanely difficult. Example: spends a single lecture on natural language processing not even teaching, but showing students how to set up Jupyter Notebooks. Then assigns a quiz AND assignment on coding machine learning language models. I am teaching myself here, what am I paying for. I am speechless.

His lectures are useless. Instead of teaching the material during class time (which is the entire point of a lecture), he uses it as a Q&A where he usually spends more than 10 minutes answering a simple question. He also spends more time telling us what to read and watch instead of just teaching it to us in person. It's ridiculous and insufferable

Every lecture feels like he was making it up on the spot. Lots of rambling and unorganized thoughts. There are a lot of mistakes on his slides during lectures as well. For our assignments, he didn't even finish the rubric and deliverable requirements before posting them online. I've never seen such a disorganized class and prof.

Worst prof I have ever had. Disorganized, didn't lecture, had in-class group work so you had to show up to hear him discuss the course syllabus every lecture the entire term. Assignments were bad and uninspired. The "midterm" was given in the final two weeks of class along with the two coding assignments. Wait for anyone else to teach 310.
He is not audible in the class. The slides are plagiarized.
He is a very nice person. Could improve his style a bit because I felt he is just reading from the slides and makes less eye contact. But graded very generously.

The class was a bit rushed by the end of the term. But he graded leniently for both midterm and finals. 
Nice guy and grading team was very generous as well.
Although the exam is difficult and contains a lot of content, the professors are kind and the grading team is generous!!!, I love him!!!
There was not enough homework to prepare for the exams, however the instructional team graded very leniently.

Crammed a lot of contents in last weeks of semester, barely responded to discussion posts or emails in a timely manner, copied all of the materials from other universities. Overall just avoid this class with this professor...

The course is copied from another university. But in that university they have a total of 135 hours of lecture, while we only had about 50. With less than half of the lecture time, we are expected to learn the same material. Steven also gave many false promises during the final week. He also accused students using bots to generate bad reviews here.

Avoid this class at all cost. the instructor instead of communicating with students and teaching better, he was mad over the comments posted here. well the comments here reflects how poorly this class was. Instead of flagging reviews, think about how you controlled this class

The whole material in the class was copied from other university. He didn't both to respond to emails and discussion posts until the end of semester. I feel like I haven't learned anything at all while paying 3.3k for a course....

It's alarming how bad this experience has been. He doesn't reply on piazza/email, he's the first professor I've seen to not hold office hours, he's unclear about the topics on his exams, he gives us Berkley's exams with no preparation for how to solve those styles of questions, and he's withholding vital information we need to study for the final.

Waste of time and money. You just watch some Youtube videos and read slides from UC Berkeley and you will be able to teach this course much better than he does. Due date changes recklessly with no announcement. Not accessible outside of class. No response to discussion forum and important questions. Not keeping promises of posting materials timely.
Hands down, it was the worst class I took...

Complete waste of time and money. He copied lectures and assignments from UC Berkeley one-to-one. I ended up learning more from UC Berkeley's CS188 videos on Youtube than from his own lectures. He also barely responds on Piazza.
terrible. after this course, I think anybody can be a professor.
let me tell you, this class was a complete joke. didn't learn anything

This was the first time he taught this course and you could kind of tell. Maybe he will be better in the future. My advice would be to rely less on the Berkeley materials. His credentials imply he has knowledge in this area and I'd love to learn it directly. Homework was easy and midterms were insane but generously graded. Nice guy just needs time.

He's great example of an instructor who doesn't care about the course. He copied lecture notes and assignments from an other university, he didn't even put a little effort to change and adapt the materials. He doesn't reply to any discussion posts or emails. The materials is useless and Bergner aced in making materials more boring by his teaching

I had so much motivation coming into this course to learn about AI and this prof has put a bad taste in my mouth. This course felt like a scam and I did not learn anything. Most of the lectures and assignments were an exact copy of UC Berkeley CS 188 and it wasn't even taught well by this prof, I had to watch UC Berkley's lectures on YouTube.
Very disappointed with the course and with SFU for having her teach it. I was excited to learn more around the topic of AI but this professor made it a terrible experience. Stay away at all costs.

She did not invest any effort in teaching this course, she copied all her lecture material from UCB and her english is so bad you can't understand a word in her lectures.There is no use of attending her class, she does not care at all about her students and her teaching. She is a copy-paste being,SFU ruined the future of this course by hiring her.

Sedaghat: I get paid for ctrl-c and ctrl-v.
Nelsen: Pathetic, I get paid terrorizing broke university students

Do yourself a favour and stay away from her. SFU should know better than to hire unknowledgeable and 
inexperienced professors to teach a 3rd-year course. She is unorganized and unresponsive and not accessible after class. She can't even teach the lectures she directly copies from UC Berkeley, not to mention her English is mid at best.

1) Instructions for assignments are vague. Can be changed on a whim, depending on her mood. Example: announcing mandatory presentations two days in advance. 

2) Lectures aren't engaging or very helpful. You will need to learn material on your own with outside resources. 

3.) Assignments are stupidly long and difficult. Prepare to cry.

Shes very unorganized with her scheduling, not only with lectures, but also assignments. She released a 18 page assignment covering things she never taught in the last week.
She's also not accommodating at all during COVID times, and doesn't accept sick notes from non SFU doctors.

The prof copies her entire lecture from UC Berkely CS 188 but in an extremly dry, uninteresting and rough way. As a result, assignments are a pain to slog through. In addition to surprise group presentations with 2 days notice.

She's not cruel or malicious, just inexperienced. Which makes this course a terrible experience

Material was copied from UC Berkeley and had minimal to no changes. The pacing in the beginning was very slow and we took that for granted, at the end she speed ran the rest of the material.  Beware of pop final project presentations. Also sent a really long homework out of nowhere that is on very rushed material, which is also due during finals

She's the most unorganized and unengaged prof I have ever had. She just copies slides from other universities and still can't teach the material. Save your money and google the material, you'll learn more than she could ever teach. She ran out of time at the end of the term and loaded us with a 20-page assignment on material she hasn't taught yet.

This is the most immersive class I have ever taken. They actually got an AI to teach us intro to AI. Unfortunately, this AI is clearly still in its early stages of training. Can't recommend her to anyone until she has finished her training. Shame on SFU for making us the training set.

A waste of time and money

inst,eecs,berkeley,edu

First off she copies everything from CS188 from Berkeley, including all her slides and assignments. Unfortunately, the quality of teaching was nowhere near that level. Furthermore, we were given less than a days  notice that we had to give a live presentation of our final project. PainChamp

Offers no educational value. Lectures didn't help with assignments had to google a lot of them or other classes just taught them better. It was more useful to watch youtube videos than attend her lectures that the majority of the class just didn't attend. Made last-minute changes to presentations a day before and didn't publicly announce them.
She teaches very little in class, and few people actually go to class. She uses UC Berkeley's class materials directly, but she teaches poorly. The exam was very difficult.

First, her English is so bad that her browser's favorites even have the folder Learning English. Secondly, the course content is an exact copy of UC Berkeley's CS188. Third, she cannot explain the content in UC Berkeley's slides. Fourth, the content is very easy based on what she teaches, but the assignments and exams are very difficult.
Very bad. VERYBAD

Disappointed by his rude behavior towards students. I do not know why he is aggressive so much? I respect the fact that you are a professor, but that does not mean you should treat everybody else as inferior to you.

The worst Instructor I have ever met, everything copied from CS188, but did not provide any help. he seldom answer question in piazza. he is lazy but extremely strict. This course itself puts a lot of pressure on us. he didn't provide any help, just give us a Berkeley link. the only thing he did is to keep adding difficulties and pressure to us

After the course was converted into online class, he disappeared. CS188 lasts for six months but we have three months and no effective help. He does't spend any time thinking about how to teach better, but making lots of complicated and strict examination rules, and he would fail people without hesitation, even under this situation. Avoid him!!!!!

Yes, like the other reviews said there wasn't enough time for the exam and he wasn't the most accommodating. By the end though, he removed a lot of restrictions and listened to student feedback on Piazza. He was also fairly active on there with answering questions. The move to online courses due to COVID-19 was not handled well by him though.

During my time at SFU this prof was the worst prof. The only thing he's good at is talking about AD Basically he doesn't do anything except copying and using UCB lectures No quizzes, no sample exams(Too lazy to write one), The only good thing about his classes is his voice(very quite and sleepy) which makes his class perfect for sleeping and gmng

The course was instructed in an unreasonably lazy manor. You are literally paying money to teach yourself everything. No problem sets, exams or quizzes were given in class, and we were directly pushed into taking a ridiculously hard final which was worth a huge chunk of the class! Steer clear!!

Do not fall for the good ratings for this prof. He basically only showed up and asked us if we had questioned, expected us to learn from a FREE set of lecture slides from Berkeley, didnt even put in effort to teach us during these hard times. The final was insanely short, with four difficult questions where you had to just read for half of the time

Too hard as an introductory course for AI. The slides were taken from UC Berkeley and he put bare minimum effort when teaching. Better off going over the material from Berkeley's website than going to class. The course was designed for a 4 credit course, but was taught as a 3 credit course. Overall horrible experience wouldnt recommend it to anyone

His lecture slides were directly copied from the UC Berkley's intro to AI class, which wouldn't be a problem except that the prereqs were different and we weren't given the full content. All the exam practise problems were from UCB, and were virtually impossible to solve and the final exam was the main deciding factor for grades.

He doesn't care about his class. Lectures and projects are taken from UC Berkeley's CS188. While other professors tried to find a way to give online lectures during COVID-19, he sent us the playlist of Berkeley's CS188 video lectures. He doesn't respect his students. Taking this course is like paying for a free online course and the credits.

He puts zero effort in his classes and doesn't care about the students at all. All the material is copied from cs188 Berkeley and even though the video lectures from cs188 Berkeley class are from 2014, they are way better than his lectures. Do not take his course with him, I repeat DO NOT TAKE THIS COURSE WITH HIM.
His lecture slides, assignments, lectures, videos, demos and even autograders were taken from Berkeley's online free lecture. He puts minimal effort to his class

pretty easy course, but he made it extra difficult with bad lecture notes, and ambigeous assignment where most of the time was spent wadding through e-mails correcting errors and explanations.  Then he goes and makes some lame extension of the final project a couple days before it was due.

Not a nice guy, he chewed someone out in class and told them not to come back because they were "apparently" making a distracting face while he was teaching? (Unprofessional?) Project was unbelievably hard and seemed to have little or no direction.  Tested material presented in lectures though.
Course Materials were not too difficult. Like others said, instructions on course project were main sent in email...very frustrating trying to go over each of those emails...
My god, the course project was so hard. The course material was fairly straightforward though. He seems to make easy concepts more difficult than they should be.

Never available for extra help. His office hours are useless since he doesn't really answer any of your questions. And if you have time conflicts with his office hour, then too bad, you'll have to ask him stuff through email coz he does not make apptment.
He is not available when needed and he sends instructions for assignments via email and expects you to know every detail of every one.  Very unclear lecture notes.
No Comments

He just tried to write as much as he can on overhead every class. I don't think this is the right way to teach. No question print out for Project. The info of project are on 20 e-mails. You have to go through every -mails carefully
Nice guy - he's clearly interested in the material. His lectures are good (not the best speaker, but makes good notes), but his assignments are very confusing.
He has a good heart, but he needs some teaching skills.

Hadley knew his stuff, and tried to share some of it, but was unsuccessful. He is very disorganized and does not provide clear assignment documents, preferring to send 50 vague emails instead. Midterm avg = 54%, 45% on midterm = instant course fail.

Lectures are dry, but he knows his stuff. To be honest, I didn't like the content, it was very symbolic and theoretical (I think that's where he specializes in). The first 2 assignments were interesting, got to apply algo's learned in class. The second half of the sem was very theoretical, didn't enjoy it as much. Lots of extensions. Exams tough.

Jen's class got more difficult near the end of the course but he did a great job on making the midterm and final related to course material. Most of the questions were things we did on the assignments. He is also easy to contact and quick to answer questions and puts in a lot of effort to helping students. Gave lots of assignment extensions.
His assignments were average but EXAMS will drop your grade so bad! It was hard to understand his lectures as well.
Lecture notes very terse with awkward handwriting. Lacking structure in materials taught and over-expands on too many topics. However, he does present the logic of things quite clearly.
The most disrespectful professor I've ever had.

Lectures are well organized so if you follow them and read the notes, you'll do fine on the quizzes. He delegates the marking of assignments and the final pair project to the TAs you're assigned so he will not answer any questions about marking. But he's willing to answer any other questions for hours after lecture which is great for online classes

Toby is the definition of a low effort prof, who spends most of his time rambling about his opinions on non-technical topics. For an upper-division course, he didn't share his area of expertise/research into the lecture much. Best of all, for ML section he just showed us three 30 mins youtube videos in class.

Toby's CMPT310 wasn't much technical. The final exam was a memory test with no problem solving questions. The midterm was easy. He just changed a few words from a sample. Assignments were not easy, but marking was generous. Overall, the course is a giveaway.
Steven Pearce is extremely lazy and disorganized, but he's funny and gave me an A.

I am quite annoyed with his random grading policy. For example, he let final grade subsitute midterm if you do better in final. His final is simply ~7 questions hinted in class. They are too easy for those who memorize them but too hard for those who not. The final can take 70% percent so you will expect 10% per question haha.

Honestly not as horrible as his reputation. Pearce is disorganized and reads off slides for lectures. He's busy but lazy. For the final he helped us by giving out several "hints" in class; many questions were the same as the ones he hinted at. Great guy to have a discussion/talk with, but maybe not the best at introducting a new topic to students.
Exams are based on luck. Depends if you memorized the correct question he chose. You dont end up learning anything in this class. It's a GPA lottery based on memorization.
Don't recommend him... Extremely unprofessional, reads off of slides only, and assignments and exams are not relevant and helpful for learning the material.
SO goooood!!! easy course. This guy can be your best prof in your life

Only thing done in class is just read lecture notes and tell some jokes. Can not solve students question. My grandma also can teach this course as long as if she can speak English but without telling some jokes.

Disorganized, disrespectful and distressing. Presentation slides are excessively long with little emphasis on importance of subjects, and often include numerous errors. Quick to belittle students for asking for clarification on "trivial" topics. Lectures are completed as quickly as possible and typically end early.

I'm not too sure how this man is employed, unprofessional, abrasive, disorganized, sloppy, and inattentive. His emails look like they were sent by someone in grade 11 and he never seems to know what materials he has actually given out. Worst part is, the midterm was worth 30% but was only out of 25 marks.

One of the most bizarrely abusive professors I've ever taken. I don't remember him being half this bad before COVID.
Sends out flurries of emails to the entire class, blaming students for not understanding "trivial" things when he gets several questions about the same topics. Just overall a weird and unpleasant class.

The worst professor, no doubt!! It's the first time he take over CMPT 310 and the lecture is sooooo messy without any logic. It seems that he knew nothing about AI, but just repeat what the textbook said

Does not know anything about the course material he has not been able to answer questions that students have asked him to clarify. Slides are always disorganized and have errors in them every week. Course content and assignment and projects are disconnected. The worst prof that I have had in 5 years at SFU.

First of all, this is not an easy class in anyway, but this site is about the professor.  Greg Mori is one of the best professors I have ever had in SFU.  He makes sure that all the students understand the material, he is super friendly and I would take any class with him again, even though I did poorly in this class.

Excellent Professor! He cares students so much that although some materials in lecture might be hard, he will explain and show examples more than once until he made sure that everyone can understand. You will find the course under his teaching become interesting. Some assignments takes time, but both TA and he will give detailed instruction!
Great prof. Knowledgeable, good lectures, interesting assignments, available for help. I recommend taking 310 with him.

young & engergetic prof, always try to make lectures fun tho the material is so dull; allows cheat sheets; long assignments (could be done in groups); he made AI even more awesome; robot soccer!! don't get frustrated by huge pile of readings; just follow his notes
Very good prof. Excellent teaching ability. Very clear, funny, and down to earth about a complex theoretical subject. His assignments are not the easiest but he was overall fair I think.
Awesome prof. However, he's a little dismissive of genetic algorithms.  ;P
great prof. will take his course again at any cost.

Fair assignments and tests. Very sympathetic of students, it's like he still remembers what it's like to be one :O
 
 Also, very sexy.
He is very easy to follow, awesome lectures but... he rushes through the course quite a bit.
Best computing science prof at SFU.  If you have the chance to take this course with him, do it.

Excellent Prof. Lectures are informative and interesting. You learn excellent techniques that are practical in real life. Very helpful. One of the best profs I've ever had! If he is teaching, take that course!
The best prof ever. Extremely easy and very interesting. If you get a chance to take a class with him do it!
Dr. Oveisi was very helpful, if you make the attempt to do well, then this course will not be difficult. Go to lectures and his office hours, he is very willing to help his students succeed.

Mehrdad gave me a lot of intuitions throughout this course. He explained things clearly using good examples and analogies. Assignments and exams are easy, as long as you understand concepts. Mehrdad's office hour (three times a week) and mail list are the most helpful. If you really want to learn, you can learn lots.
Mehrdad is the very nice CMPT prof!He is willing to help everyone, also he try to help people get high mark! Very nice prof!!!!! cheers!!!

Is extremely helpful. Very willing to email out a lot of help. The course is entirely taught with powerpoint slides, which means that you don't really have to be there. The material is EXTREMELY boring. Very disappointing content. If you think AI is going to be about being bots and stuff get read to be underwhelmed. Mostly about search algorithms.

She has excellent slides, and her assignments were fair. I give her a lower mark because her accent is unbearably strong, which is distracting from the lecture content. Also, written exams for a computer science class??

I took cmpt 300 with her as well. With Hazra you are safe as she makes everything reasonable. However, I won't take any courses with her because I don't like her reading lecture notes without enough explanation.
One of the following statements is true. A: The AI course is boring. B: Hazra has made this course boring. If I did this multiple choice question, I would choose B.

Good professor. Clear slides, good range of activities that make up your grade, and material isn't too difficult imo. Assignments are a mix of theory + coding (python). Prof is very caring and nice. Only complaint is that the final was too long for the time given, but the prof did address this in the final marks. Would take Hazra again!

Dr. Imran is a great prof who genuinely cares about student's learning and understanding of the materials. Having taken 310 and spoken with previous 310 students (not in Dr. Imran's class), unless needed as a pre-req, there are far more useful upper level CMPT courses offered in the department (i.e. avoid 310 if possible and spend money elsewhere!)

The teaching isn't amazing or anything she expects us to read the textbook and teaches everything very slow during lectures. Low workload and it's easy to get a good grade in her class. But we're paying to learn and I didn't learn much from this course and it's basically a waste of money. I'd take a real professor as Hazra is just a temporary prof

She is not bad at managing the course but didn't make students learn something practical or interesting. To be honest, the course was a waste of time. She should work on the course curriculum rather than making over-detailed marking schemes for outdated assignments. She has a caring attitude even though her teaching skill isn't on the great side.
very helpful prof, and the course content is not too hard to study or understand. The marking is fair, and the workload is not heavy too. Recommend if this prof is teaching again

I took this class to learn AI. To be fair, a pro of Hazra is her workload is quite fair and easy. However, I really didn't learn anything in her class. Her lectures made no sense. Office hours weren't of much help either. I don't care if she marks hard or not, I just want to learn something and unfortunately I didn't (I did all the readings btw).

Hazra is a decent professor and tries to make her class relevant. It's important to do textbook readings. The final exam was challenging. It is not just memorizing definitions but being able to see a scenario and understanding the concept. My grades dropped from A to A-. I learned a lot and enjoyed the course. Hope to take more classes with her.

Hazra is a great professor and I would definitely recommend her for CMPT 310. I have never taken a course as structured as hers. She gave us five assignments. All assignments were very interesting. There were quizzes, in-class activities, polling questions, recordings. On top of it, very caring and accessible. One of the best AI profs at SFU.

Such a lovely person and a dedicated professor. Her interest in the success of her students is really evident. Those who'd say different were probably the students who are mad about not getting easy grades. I truly enjoyed her class.

Hazra is so detailed, clear and organized. Her teaching style would suit the majority of the students! Keep doing all your practices! She's also very responsive with piazza and emails. She's beyond amazing!

Hazra explains and teaches in a way that I wish all professors taught. She cares about her students and ensures that every aspect of a topic is addressed so everyone will understand. Truly a blessing!
I enjoyed her class. She knows her stuff. She teaches at such a comfortable pace. She goes through everything so thoroughly. An amazing prof who I would recommend to anyone.

Even though this semester was online, the performance was below acceptable. Most of her lectures didn't make sense and she just told everyone to read the textbook or slides beforehand (even though many ppl did...) Her final exam dropped me from an A to a C+, my lowest mark in my entire academic career. Never take a class with Hazra Imran.

Participation marks are worth a lot of marks for what they are. Her lectures are more theoretical heavy. There is a lot of repeat from previous courses. A big con is she is bad at communicating what she wants.

A decent instructor. She focuses heavily on the theory side of Ai instead of interesting things like ML. Assignments weren't very interesting. Fair marker, approachable, and she knows her stuff. Feels like sometimes she jumps around on a subject, could have better logical order. Overall a prof that I wouldnt avoid, but I wouldnt jump to either.

Poor teaching skills. Maybe she is a good researcher, but she cannot teach unfortunately. Only pro I can think of is the course workload is fair. Honestly, I feel like I learned nothing this term in this class...

Pros : relatively light courseload/ fair exams & assignments/ she tries to help students Cons : she makes easy concepts complicated (wordings in the slides should be improved)/ old and not very useful course materials/ not the great administration (lecture cancellation with short notice, couldn't finish scheduled activities and sections, etc.)

Hazra is a kind prof. She spends a lot of time explaining the material. And it's easy to get an A-range grade with her. If this's your purpose dig in 100%. But if your goal is to learn a lot about AI - FORGET. The entire semester you will be remembering CMPT225, MACM101, and STAT270. No practice at all. All assignments are theoretical.

Hazra is one of my favourite profs at SFU. She cares for student learning. Her slides are informative and present real and useful examples. The online environment is challenging for everyone. I am enjoying her course. Would love to have more courses with her.

Lots of activities in a remote class, so don't fall behind. Communication could be better. Read the textbook before class to understand the lecture It feels like she cares about her students but has a hard time putting herself in our position. Can come off as a bit rude (like when using caps lock), but that might be due to online communication

Hazra is one of the best instructors in the CS department. Lectures are clear and a lot of opportunities to learn the materials through in-class activities quizzed and try out exercises. The workload is medium. Would recommend taking an AI course with her.

She is *definitely* the worst instructor of the department. Powerpoints are jam-packed with confusing information, and she's impossible to understand. No time is left for comprehension, she just speeds by everything. Highly unethical of SFU to make us pay for such poor quality education. Will complain to department if she doesn't improve by the end

Excellent Professor! He cares students so much that although some materials in lecture might be hard, he will explain and show examples more than once until he made sure that everyone can understand. You will find the course under his teaching become interesting. Some assignments takes time, but  he will give detailed instruction!
Honestly, his knowledge is not  enough to teach and manage the course.

If you enjoy every piece of information taught to you right out of a text book this is your guy. He covers material way too quickly without proper explanations or examples(a chapter every few days). His assignment were tough and so were his exams. This was the first computing science class I ever got a D in.
Great prof, course is not that hard for a upper division CS course.

Great guy. This course is very interesting to me and is actually not hard. His lectures were interesting, assignments and exams were pretty fair to me although I do messed up the last assignment...but interesting enough I've got pretty high marks on his mid term and final. Be advised, START YOUR ASSIGNMENTS EARLY OR YOU'LL MESS THEM UP.
Nice guy :) He explains things very clearly

Knowledgeable, personable, interesting, and clear.  Better than many profs in the faculty, even though he is a sessional.  For those who commented that the assignments/tests were too hard, you are clearly not ready for upper-division CS,as this was one of the easier and clearer courses I've taken.

Helpful, knowledgeable, personable.  Knows his material well, and can teach it well. To the previous commenters that claim the assignments/exams were too hard, you are clearly not ready for upper division CS, as this was a relatively clear and easy course.

Easy Assignments, If your not clear with what to do go and ask him directly during his office hour, he is helpful.the last assignment is hard (given the time) limited time but tons of things to do, not if your taking 1 course.The only thing i dont like about his course is his final exam, extremely hard! From A+ to B-
Thanks a lot. Hassan. I've had a lot of fun in your class. Hope you do well in the future.
Hard assignments and exams
Interesting assignments and final.
Sometimes hard to follow the class. Assignments and exams were fair except the time for midterm. Generally recommended
Good lectures. Would repeat until everyone understands. Fair exams. Recommended.
Liked his style
Lecures were a bit confusing. Markings is fair.
Not the worst prof, but  defintely could have been better! Assignments are tough. I would have taken this with another prof if I could do this again.

always has a lot to talk about the subject, so you learn much more than what is in the slides. Comparing with previous terms he is updating his teachings slids and assignments every term to match his style better. You will learn alot of programming since he loves hands-on approach it seems.

He is very enthusiastic about the topic and try to convey that to students. Try to review the material before going to lectures. He posts alot of stuff. So being prepared gets that much farther in learning when he is discussing the material. Be prepared to work hard.

Honestly this course would improve alot if he organized the course, got rid of the quizzes and structured the slides to fit his teaching style instead of ripping off Berkeley. I think if he implemented these changes he would be honestly a great prof.

Hello how does he have 3 rating. It should be at like 0. No hate to the guy. Buddy is nice and all. Feel bad for the hate he gets sometimes too. BUT he does not know how to teach. Like I am not joking. In terms of learning, this class is absolute trash. Nothing he says makes any sense, and i m not tryna to overexaggerate here. dont take it with him

Absolutely insane. So unorganized and uninterested. Would not reply to important emails and doesn't even know how to do a simple question himself (blamed Berkeley's answers to be wrong). Made our final diabolically hard for no reason, and added a question in the midterm which no one could self, including him. SFU do better.

Extremely unclear about directions. will give different, contrasting information in lectures, emails, and tutorials. Seems very confused in lectures, like they don't know what they are doing.

If you're reading this, please organize your information better, don't make receiving course information a scavenger hunt.
I just started out with him and after the first lecture I had to drop, it was probably one of the worst lectures I had at SFU. To be honest, I have no clue how he is a prof. NEVER TAKE!
I do not recommend!

What he taught us was not sufficient for the exams. The lecture slides are mostly Berkeley lectures. The final was a disaster(the worst final in my entire degree) but still managed to get a good score due to his lenient marking. The lectures were kinda boringone can easily study everything from UC Berkeley.
he is okay, but this course overall requries too much self studying and reading with him.
He's the GOAT
Great prof. Funny and caring. Looks good in a leather jacket. yes.
GOAT. Made challenging concepts seem easy. Super funny and caring. Really cool assignments too, and the exams are difficult but fair.
very good prof

Just a copy paste of uv Berkeley and stills manages to mess everything up. Exams are nothing like the Berkeley ones or practice samples as he changes them to a point that only he can understand. Save yourself from him.

Please do not take this course with him. Man does not know what he is teaching. He just knows how to yap and dodge questions. Copies everything from UC Berkeley. Also, someone should tell him that he is not funny.

In CMPT 310, I found my stride,
With Nezami there to be my guide.
From AI paths to search and play,
He made the hardest things feel okay.

The code we wrote was not just code,
But steps along a thinker's road.
Assignments tough, yet somehow fair,
With just enough of challenge there.
Took his course, leveled up. Brain went brrr. 10/10 would recommend. If you miss out? That's a you problem.
Midterms and final were super fair  no surprises. If you go to class and review slides, you'll be fine. He doesn't try to catch students off guard like some other profs.

Exams were fair, focused more on understanding than memorization. Assignments were challenging but doable if you keep up. He's really responsive via email and is open to questions  never made anyone feel dumb for asking something.

Honestly one of the best profs I've had at SFU. Dr. Nezami explains concepts like minimax, CSPs, and adversarial search in a super clear way and actually makes AI feel approachable. He uses real-world examples and gives lots of helpful hints before assignments. The slides are super well-organized and he actually cares if students are learning.
My Glorious King. Ignore the bad reviews.

Terrible experience. During the entire semester I had no idea what is going on all thanks to reza. Save yourself from torture and wasting money. There are tons of other reviews I would recommend reading so that you know how great the prof is and why you should avoid him

Reza is such a bad prof. Ya maybe he is a nice person, even the nicest person out there. But i dont care. Its horrible to learn with him. he doesn't know how to teach whatsoever, i would never suggest anyone taking the course with him. Its horrible. I don't know I passed. If you want to learn anything, you gotta learn it by yourself sadly.

He cant teach, literally everything was from UC Berkeley from lectures to asssignments. Do not trust his sample questions for both midterm and finals as they are no where near the questions appeared on the paper.

Man does not know anything. His slides are from berkley so he legit doesn't know what he's talking about sometimes. Always : uhhh, ahhhuuuh, umm yeah so ... Like does he want us to learn? Even more, he has practice problems with no solutions, if he does make solutions they are unreadable. theres writing all over the place and over the question.

He doesn't know what he's talking about, literally read of the sldies then add a few filler words that makes no sense. Dogded questions if there were any and all assignments were literally taken from CS188. Practise midterm and finals were useless.
This guys makes exams out of nowhere. he himself doesn't know what he is teaching. after he made exams on paper this semester its no longer a gpa booster. Assignments are all Berkeley ones.

No comment, never trust his samples or questions given to practice cuz his midterms and final are nowhere close to what we have.
Wont recommend

Assignments worth over half the grade and last two have auto graders which was nice. Pop quizzes sucked but aren't exactly closed book. Midterm and final includes really hard questions. Boring lectures, and some given study supplies have wrong answers which doesn't help.
Just avoid at all costs for your own good.

If there was a rating below 1, I could have given him that. He is the worst professor I have ever taken. The course he teaches has been copied from Berkeley's CS188 course. He does not know a single word what he says in the class and even provides wrong answers for practice materials. Stay away from him if possible.

Bro expects us to know partial derivates for the final exam when he didn't even teach it, nor is it a course prerequisite. Most TAs are awful, never replying to emails and no-show in office hours. Pop quizzes in big 2025. Everything is copied from Berkeley, from lecture slides to assignments to exams. Absolute clown show .
Half of his answers on the answer sheet are wrong, I have no clue what to do. Please help.

Awful professor, he has no clue what he is taking about. Everything is copied from Berkley - from the lectures slides, to assignments, to quizzes, to exams. Everything he says is incoherent as well, we still have no idea what is on our final or the cheat sheet for it.

If youre genuinely fond of AI and wanna learn. please, please DONT take this course with this dude. he's gonna brutally murder the passion you have for AI. My guy doesn't even know what he's teaching just yaps during lectures read through the slides and when you ask a question, professionally dodges the question and moves on. DONT!

Ahmedreza Nezami is truly the professor of all time. Students should marvel in his glory, but instead they seethe that he does nothing and gets PAID $_$. He implements stochastic learning in REAL LIFE, with unexpected procedures around every corner!

k-consistency? He is OK consistently to me! Just look at his reviews, many success stories.
Lectures are alright, he gives good homework questions that are similar to exam questions which is useful.
bro copy everything from berkeley, waste of time taking his course
Bro does the minimum to get his paycheck
No one knows what this guy is doing, literally disastrous. He won't teach properly, of course, because he doesn't know how to, and he also won't post materials unless reminded.
lectures are absolute cinema, take this class just to experience reza's chaos.
this N doesnt know what hes doing

One of the craziest instructors of all time. Copies everything from CS188 but is terrible at teaching. Never explains concepts clearly and chicken scratches on the slides. Save your time by skipping his lectures on weeks with no quizzes (u have to guess) and watching CS188 lectures instead. Luckily, the TAs were very helpful and lenient on marking.
If you want to learn about real-life stochastic applications then this guy is the man!!

This professor does not seem to know what he is talking about most of the time. He is the most confusing professor of all time. He is messy, and all his content is stolen from Berkeley's CS 188. Although his materials are stolen, he still manages to get them wrong. His assignments were all stolen from Berkeley, and he still manages to break them?
Learned nothing, got my A+ and dipped. W Reza, my Persian goat, who has mastered the art of yapping

Lectures could be more concise, feels like we stayed on the same slides for ages. Course content was just from Berkeley CS 188. Assignment instructions were often unclear and seemed to be missing something. Things were honestly ok, I had a solid ~90% up until the end but the final exam made me wanna off myself
This guy is on another plane of existence
Although lectures can be pretty unclear, the marking does make up for it. Learning the content ahead will get you further in this course.
He does not know what he teaches
GOAT

If you enjoy debugging confusing, spaghetti codebases, this course is perfect! Don't let the title of this course fool you with Ahmedreza, because you will learn everything that isn't AI. The lectures are just extremely bland rip-offs of CS 188 at Berkeley. 

The only positive thing about this class is that it was a GPA booster in the end.

Prof Nezami is an inspiration. He taught me that you don't have to know how to do a job to get paid for it, and that you can give online exams while banning computers. He is a master at inciting confusion, chaos, and anxiety. Clearly, we do not comprehend his higher-levels of thought. I hope one day to achieve his level of greatness.
Get out. Everything from Berkley. The course is just an emotional rollercoaster. Decided to give a final online to be taken in class but not allow anyone to bring a computer and only a cheat sheet.
This man is the man
Great instructor! Every encounter with him, online or in-person, can bring tons of surprises! Being able to predict and prepare for uncertainties is such an invaluable skill I learned from him.
Believe me, this course will be your easiest course in CMPT 300 level!

Professor Nezami is flexible. His lectures are interesting, although he was a bit slow at the beginning, he catches up. One of the assignments was tricky, but he changed the requirements and grading scheme in favor of the students, so no complaints. Overall, I enjoy his lectures and attend all of them.

Ahmedreza Nezami is truly an inspiration! His ability to communicate is impressive, shocking even! We followed the cs188 material, covering search for the first 8 weeks, followed by constraint satisfaction, reinforcement learning, adversarial search, bayes nets, perceptron systems, and machine learning. Taking his course has truly changed my life!

Professor Nezami teaching ability is beyond just mere exams and assignments, as he gets the students to learn about stochastic principles and uncertainty in real life scenarios, with ever-changing due dates and requirements. You will have to adopt principles of AI in your own learning, which greatly enhances the experience.

This guy is the guy! He went to lectures and said something! (I think, wasn't there). A word of caution however, you may need to bring your own final to the class! His printer doesn't work! I personally brought a coloring book to show how I understood constraint satisfaction on coloring maps or something like that!
Doesn't know what Ai is. Never too sure what to teach like a toxic gf. If you know how to code you pass the course. Any course you take it would be debugging 101

This professor is one of the professors of all time, the negative reviews are LYING to you! Throughout the course he has been in class, and he has done stuff. Further, he also looks pretty swag. I am confident that a course with Ahmedreza Nezami will truly be an inspirational experience, impacting your view on education for the rest of your life!
This is course is insane. The prof is game changer
You never know what could happen with this guy.
He's the man
Best prof ever. Highly flexible and unorganized. Exams are take home, depending on mood he might cancel it.
Man, this guy took it to the next level. Never had a professor like this.

Ahmedreza Nezami has no idea what he's even teaching. Lectures are a whole lot of nothing useful. You are much better off watching CS188 Berkeley lectures as they are more entertaining and MUCH better in terms of content. Assignments are incredibly vague and few guidelines. Low workload but I learned absolutely nothing from the lectures and prof.

He doesn't have any office hours for this course, so reaching him is difficult. The course is a famous CS188 UCB course, and he is not familiar with the materials. Better lectures are available on Youtube for the identical course.

However, CS188 itself is a pretty good course, so the assignments that comes with it is good practice.
The assignments and exams are very easy, and he gives you a lot of practice material to succeed. His lectures aren't great, but just watch the CS188 Berkeley lectures and you'll do fine.
The lectures were not the best but there were good alternatives online. Grading was also pretty lenient and fair.

Administration in this course was the worst I've seen in my four years as an undergrad. Two weeks wasted due to snow day and midterm lead to content overload towards the end, and this is the first final where I had no clue what to write. Did not show up to proctor his own midterm, and showed up late to his own final. Actions show a lack of care.

He and his TAs don't answer questions on Piazza often, but when they do it's only partial information. The last month and a half was extremely rushed and surface-level. Overall very disappointing quality teaching. 
You can use CS188 UC Berkeley material at home to get a good grade. All content is taken from there, assignments, exams, everything.

The professor seems to have left every responsibility to the TAs and the University of Berkeley. The material is taught poorly, nobody answers questions in piazza, and the sample exams have the same question copy-pasted 5 times and little resemblance to the actual exams. Can't believe I paid for the exact free online course with added stress, shame

Most Prof usually try their best to simplify complex and abstract concepts to spark students' interest and encourage active thinking. However, this Prof made the simple course extremely complicated, making me feel disgusted with the topic of AI, which I used to be very interested in. Hang Ma is not suitable for teaching a introductory courses!

RUN! The professor gave a very easy sample exam and a very, very hard real exam. You can't get any helpful information from the sample exam. The question type, number of questions, and difficulty of the questions have nothing to do with your actual exam. The level of teaching is completely out of proportion to the difficulty.

This professor doesn't know how to teach a course. The teaching in the first two months was extremely slow, but in the last month, we almost covered 3/4 of the entire semester's content. There's less than a week left until the final exam, but we still don't even know the scope of the exam! He never sends any emails or announcements to students!

Hang Ma is one of the most lazy and unaware profs I ever had. He doesn't respond to any emails/piazza posts from students and unaware of incorrect grading from TAs. The whole course is copied from UC Berkleys CS188 class, where its the same slides, assignments, and even tests. Basically, you're paying for a course that's online on the internet.

Avoid this professor and his TA! He is really overrated!! His attitude towards teaching is very negative, many uncertainties in this course. The lecture notes and assignments are completely copied from UC Berkeley CS188 (thanks UCB) without any modification. I cannot understand I paid tuition for public resources that can be fully searched online.

I am OK with using good materials for teaching. But the experience of taking this course was so bad, the TA made me feel I am a guilty person. Although many students didn't cheat, they still got 0 for assignments (the number of people who got 0 halved in a few days). This prof leaves everything to TA, and the course is really lack of transparency.

SFU should investigate this course. Why are all his lecture materials and assignments copied from other university, with no punish for him? TA frequently sends threatening emails to students, claim they have a software to check cheating, but many of the accusations are unjustified. Taking this course has caused me a lot of fear and mental stress!!!

His exams are excessively difficult! Before the exam, the TA provide a sample midterm, but the difficulty level of the sample questions was relatively easy. However, the actual exam was 100 times harder than the sample midterm! Many people thought this was a relatively easy exam based on sample exam, but the actual exam was extremely hard!

Please avoid this professor and his TA! 

His TA accuses students of cheating without any direct evidence. So far, more than 50 people have received 0 for assignment 1 and assignment 2 due to cheating accusations! We have around 130 students taking this course, and it is not possible for each person to invent a different algorithm.

The professor does not care about students AT ALL. Never get contact with him, Never reply to emails, Even not show up on midterm day. Never met a professor like this. All the announcements come from TAs, even when 33 out of 110 people get 0 in their homework,  still the TA sent out the email. Don't know what's wrong with the professor's email0

This whole course including the assignments is copied from UC Berkeley CA188, not a single word was modified. Professor just read the slides, the original UCB lecture on youtube are way better than this professor's lecture. 1/3 of people get 0 for one assignment because there are similarities in some of their functions.

The course material is very enjoyable (tho copied from UC berkley's introduction to AI slide by slide) and I do enjoy the lectures, but I was one of MANY accused of cheating on an assignment worth 10% because my solution was similar to another students by chance. The algorithm isn't complicated and it's very easy to have similar implementations.

On some sort of mission to find academic dishonesty when it isn't there. Accused 33 students of AD when they wrote code based on the pseudocode in the slides. Complete disconnect between prof & TAs, both of whom say contradicting information about the course. Midterm is nothing like the assignments or sample exam. Avoid at all costs!!

Okay, this professor is overrated. All his slides are not his own.. If we did this with our homework, it would be considered plagiarism and would send us to academic dishonesty. However, when a professor does it, nothing happens.  This professor didn't give us practice problems prior to the midterm and go through them with us.

The entire course has been ripped from UC Berkeley. Prof just reads from the UCB slides. Prof & TAs are not on the same page. A week beforehand, TAs tell us that the midterm exam is on the first two lectures and then a couple days later tell us its on all lectures. No practice or homework apart from coding assignments. AVOID AT ALL COSTS!
On the final u can see hard questions accounting for about 25% percent comes from topics not covered in assignments.

The professor often struggled to explain the slides. Homework grading was severely delayed, with two weeks of no activity. The final exam had numerous errors requiring multiple corrections. Given the high ratings, I was very disappointed. Take the other professor because you can get a better grade, you have to do self-learning anyway.

The final exam was terrible. Although calculators were allowed, the exam had obscure questions, mistakes, and unclear wording that baffled even the TAs. It felt more like a test of our patience and endurance than of our understanding of the material.

Active answering on Piazza, lectures comprehensive. Exams more convoluted/confusing than necessary, other UD CS & math exams more straightfoward. Midterm: No calculator but had a long calculation w/ decimals. Final exam: Calculator allowed but asked obscure question, mistakes in questions, unclear wording that even TA was confused with when asked.

Angelica's class was decent and I'll cut her some slack since she tried to redo the course with new material. The course contents were pretty much identical to UCB. Overall the lectures were good and exams were fair apart from some final questions. Enjoyed my time in the course.

Garnered a lot of sympathy with performative caring (talks about reading RMP + Discord), but did little to actually help students. Idc that she uses someone else's slides. I do care that she didn't bother learning them first. Her reputation is propped up by her demeanour rather than teaching ability. It's clear she put in minimal effort.

Too much individual assignment weight (only 3 assignments, not enough topic covered) + TAs make them, so can be too hard, also require knowledge outside prerequisites. Lectures had mistakes sometimes, but overall organized selection helpful to introduce AI. Exams feel like trivia, need to memorize names and read textbook (some info not on slides!)

If you just want easier UD credits for grad, this is the course to take. It takes some work to get good grades yes, but you can literally coast (spending 3 hrs max / wk) to class avg. She is nice, but don't expect to get much out of her lectures. All borrowed material including proj (few). Wkly exercise = free marks. Again, EZ UD credits.
Angelica is awesome, you can tell she genuinely wants us to learn about the material
She tells you not to use ChatGPT for your assignments while she copied all her slides form Berkeley without referencing them. What does that tell you?

Dr. Lim presents the course material straightforwardly, and I can tell a lot of thought was put into developing the content. It only includes the relevant parts in a traditionally VERY content-heavy, outdated and boring course. Assignments/tests are graded on understanding- not memorization. Make sure you go over your math fundamentals. Fun class!

Dr. Lim is an excellent professor and I recommend 310 with her. The pre reqs aren't up to date as of now so be sure to have a little calculus and linear algebra but she has helped the class get up to date. Challenging topics so be ready to learn outside of class and use the resources she makes available. Dr. Lim cares about her students success

I'm just entirely amazed at the lazy negative comments for Prof Lim it makes no sense you're in CS at SFU, people. Do you think it's easy? Ignore the negative course feedback if you're actually here to learn.

For serious students who are actual adults: Prof Lim is extremely bright, she's very accessible if you actually ask her questions!

I came here to comment that our midterm for this course was the 29th so take the bad reviews leading up with a grain of salt, great prof imo and makes tough content manageable. We got to do weekly activities in place of an extra lecture and they help me a lot.

Love this class & prof. Content challenging but manageable. Follow lecture examples (versus just re-doing assignments/activities) for exams, my learning. Dr. Lim has entertaining, engaging lectures and integrates topics within the broader picture (industry, current research). Huge course, good to be familiar with topics.10/10 recommend.

The recent comments about Dr. Lim's instruction in CMPT 310 have been rather harsh. Dr. Lim has great expertise & is doing her best in taking a traditionally difficult/confusing course, and delivering it to us with modernity, clarity, and depth. She's clear, approachable, provides relevant resources. If you're taking 310, she is a solid choice.

The professor is kind and genuinely passionate about the subject, but she struggles to teach effectively. In one class, students had to explain content from her own slides to her. The slides themselves are taken from Berkeley/Stanford, and she often comes unprepared for lectures.

Seems like a nice person, but her 310 class is definitely not good. She can't explain the slides well (as they are copied from Stanford/Berkely), and attending lecture becomes essentially useless. 100% of my learning in this course has been from Youtube.

I was excited to take 310 with Angelica after seeing all her great reviews. She copies all her course materials from Stanford and Berkeley and does not know what she's talking about. She does not prepare for lectures and all her materials (including the ridiculous assignments) are made by the TAs. She only gets by with her "nice" personality.

Jim did not put in much effort for the class. The notes were poor, and many things were not explained. His assignments were not sufficiently explained, and he did not give good feedback. He packed in too much content for the course, as it should be an introduction to AI.

The only instructor who are not willing to help students during my 4 years university life. However, he can't even explain his own slides and textbook questions properly in class. Get ready to teach yourself.

His lectures are average. Biggest problem is he doesn't like answering questions. Often times, he gives non-answers, shrugs, walks away, and tells us "that should explain enough", which it clearly logically doesn't. I sense a hint of animosity or condescendence from him, or perhaps it's just a manifestation of his lack of passion towards teaching.

1. Not accessible after class. Gives non-answers and will walk away from you. Quite rude 2 Lectures are theoretical with little examples. The examples given are a mess 3 Marking is terrible 4 Unresponsive to email 5 Changes assignments after they were given without notifying 6 Struggled to provide solutions in class to his own test AVOID HIM

Lectures were extremely dry. Examples were very few and far between making the material difficult to grasp right away. Did not seem interested in teaching by any stretch of the imagination. On the last day before the final, cancelled his office hours without notice and responded to my coming there with questions with "Too bad"

this is more like an english class, you learned nothing eventually because your main responsibility is to hard memorize 1000 pages of logically unrelated notes and hope that he won't ask you something outside the notes.

Ah, Jim Delgrande. Makes simple concepts appear much more difficult because of his lack of explanations and practical examples. He's a bit like a terrible technical writer  doesn't understand his audience's level of knowledge, and doesn't care to. Don't expect to get more than a "check the textbook" answer to in-class questions. Avoid him.

well, i d say that his materials are easy. but the way he taught us is very confusing and hard. he maybe a good problem solver, but not a good teacher. he can be very harsh on a sem and then very nice on the next. and unluckily i was on the harsh one

Dr. Delgrande is a good teacher and the class was quite interesting. I learned a lot about AI (something I knew nothing about before) and got introduced to functional programming too. The lectures in his class are very valuable. Definitely worth going to.

He uses his hypnotising voice to read his slides, and make you sleep like a baby. Which, all the slides you can just read them by yourself! I had been studying myself and stopped going to his lectures. And i got all perfect on my assignments, with help from my expert friend.  Lecture is boring as an English course or even worse. STAY AWAY FROM HIM!

An average professor. This class was pretty straightforward, nothing too difficult other than getting used to Racket which isn't a big deal. Nice guy too. He can be a bit scattered in his thoughts but he does know the subject. Would recommend.

He teaches from the textbook and uses slides from the textbook, which is fair. The problem is, the assignments are all about functional programming in Scheme which has nothing to do with the course topic and isn't covered in the textbook at all! He also barely covered this in the lecture. He's made an interesting course agonizing by doing this.
poor at teaching. assignments are fair but exams are irrelevant to the teaching materials. dont take his 310 course.

Assignments were very fair granted you kept up with readings and attended lectures. I got above 90% on all without too much effort. He knows the material very well, I honestly loved his class and thought he was a great prof. Don't expect an easy A though, lots of work.
poor prof
Jim might be good at his research, but not this class. The assignment is hard and exam is not relevant to the class material.
Very explanatory slides; enjoys helping students get high grades.

I wish I had never taken a course with him.  He had errors throughout his exams.  Didn't come to class for at least 2 full weeks of the semester and tested on material he didn't cover, even though he promised not to.
yes, his cmpt310 is pretty enjoyable for anyone who deserves to be in cmpt sci... but i dun understand why anyone would rate him "HOT"
Overall, he is a nice professor.
Assignments are fair. Exams are fair. In general a not too useful but enjoyable course.
Easy course with an easy prof. 10/10 would take again. Seriously I barely came to class and I'm acing up the class. She's also very nice too and gives easy questions.
Definitely a great professor, good teaching style. She's patient and helpful, would take her course in the future.

Felt that she tried to cram too much material into one semester. Lots of guest speakers. Assignments aren't too hard but sometimes need clarifying. You can tell she's very passionate about the subject and teaching CMPT in general. She genuinely wants everyone to learn and do well, and is very open to suggestions.

Diana's very nice (she even told us she would not be offended if we fell asleep in her class).  Unfortunately when she taught us 310 it ended up covering almost entirely Prolog and she gave maybe 30 minutes each to some other fundamental AI like neural networks.

No question she is a nice prof. No question she is passionate. However, if you are taking CMPT 310 (AI), DO NOT TAKE IT WITH HER. You do not learn ANYTHING in the class. She spent half of the semester teaching PROLOG, and doesn't get to some AI programming until the end of the semester. A waste of time and money.
Very well thought out teaching style. Provided a broad background of the subject and used many invited speakers to compliment her lectures. One of the best CMPT profs at SFU!

I really appreciated Dr. Schulte's enthusiasm for the material. He tried to make lectures interesting by showing different types of media. The grading criteria were a little unclear but the assignments were interesting and not that difficult.
Nice, warm, informal, error-prone, academically doubtable, 90% too easy and 10% strikingly difficult material

Dr. Schulte is one of the best lecturers I've had so far at SFU! He made this course very informative and interesting. The assignments were a little bit difficult but Oliver was always happy to help. Exams were not that hard but still required to understand the principles. The only problem was the book because it was SOO boring and overcomplicated!
Makes assignments way too easy, so you have an 80 percent average at the end and get a B- because of the curve. Didn't really learn anything useful in this class.

Oliver Schulte is the worst professor I've had at SFU. I had him for CMPT 310 as well as 354 and both courses were unstructured, uninformed gong shows. Everything you learn will be by your own effort; do not rely on this man to teach you anything. Assignments  convoluted. Exams  he allows cheat sheets. Too easy. Curved hard. Material  worthless.

Awesome prof, nothing but good things. Assignments are extremely long and easy to mess up. If you put in the time, it prepares you for the final + midterm. The problem is time (some can take up to 20 hours).  Very nice and tries really hard for students to learn - SFU could take a hint from him.

His teaching skill is below average,on the other hand, he is pretty laid-back.My biggest complain is that, the fnal is A LOT harder than the midterm,while he said in class the dificulty level should be similar.
He's sloppy and disorganize in his presentations. He cannot answer if anyone has a question. His grading is unfair. To be concise he is awful.

Very determined to teach & has genuine concern for students. He is happy when no one is lagging behind. His lectures were fun & the assignments I did were very practical. If you really want to learn, you can combine the lectures and textbook(naturally).The problem is that students dont like to read. He is one of the best and inspiring profs ever.

Googled some of his lecture notes and found that they were stolen with his name plastered onto them instead. Teaching ability is pretty average, but his assignments are ambiguous and he falls behind the lecture schedule. He obviously doesn't do the assignments first because the second one had an impossible question that later had to be removed.

In my opinion he's fine at best. I actually liked the class a lot. But, at least for me, his answers to any questions (during lectures of office hours) were useless because he just repeats himself. Assignments (especially programming assignments) were really fun. Exams were fair.

The assignments are the most brutal I've ever done. They take far too long to complete and Maxwell does not go very in depth in class about the concepts and goes over complex algorithms very quickly yet expects you to implement them in Python. The class was not very fun in my opinion, however, it is easy to get a good mark as the class is 50% asgns

As a professor Libbrecht is ok. He rushes through topics fairly quickly so come to lecture prepared. The 4 assignments in this class are time consuming so it may be wise to start them early. Overall 310 is a must-take for anyone interested in the field of AI!

Easiest CMPT class I've taken. 4 assignments were a bit time consuming but very doable, midterm was SUPER easy, final was slightly difficult but was scaled a decent amount. Lectures were decent and he'll prob be even better in future semesters. You have access to lecture recordings from a previous sem, anyways, which help a lot.

Max is one of the best CMPT profs at SFU. He explains topics very clearly and sets the students up to succeed. There were 4 assignments, each taking 20 hours with an included autograder so you basically know what mark you'll get. The first 2 assignments were pretty fun! Bonus marks for answering classmates' questions on Piazza. Tests are very fair

The biggest problem with this course is that the lectures do not prepare you for the assignments, which were all very difficult and time consuming. The midterm and final were surprisingly easy. Lectures were soso. Libbrecht's methods of handing out participation and bonus points were not fair.

There are so many bonus points, but assignments aren't easy at all. It's like actually implementing algorithms from cmpt 307 (in terms of level of difficulty, not contents ). He doesn't explain much in class, but he knows stuff....

dude's nice and knows his stuff. I'd say he's got potentials, assignments are fun, exams are between fair and easy. his lecture is unorganized and sometimes rushed, so do prepare to rewatch lecture recordings and ASK for him to explain.

Maxwell is a fine prof who has great potential. He had novel ideas on teaching (online class forum, grading scheme) and most topics were covered well. Disliked that some important/required subtopics were brushed over and the complicated grading scheme (participation, extra credit, bonuses). Good prof and nice guy, would take class again.

This is a GPA booster class. There was up to a 25% bonus on final grade. The lectures are useless: they are vague and contain many mistakes (for anyone who was in the class, recall the pseudocode for filtering and smoothing). The exams can be easily completed if you have already taken MACM101 (logic), STAT270 (probability) and CMPT307 (algorithms).
one word - worst teacher ever

Don't take this course from this prof. He is extremely unorganized. No notes will be provided. The main help was the video lecture if you want to know anything. No help for the coding assignment either. He expects a lot but don't teach that good.

Lectures are little to no use for the coding and written assignments. He covers so little that its pretty much a self-taught course. The coding assignments are frustrating at first, but going to see a TA and collabs on piazza helped. He's a nice guy, but a horrible teacher.

Seems like a nice guy, easy grades (extra credit, kind of easy assignments, 5 late days). Wants you to attend and has questions + presentations every Friday. Weekly assignments (from the questions) topics not taught. Lectures are kind of useless, doesn't teach in detail and your notes afterwards will be useless. You won't learn but you'll get an A.

Coding assignments are clear. Written assignments require external knowledge (material not covered in lecture). Content in midterm unclear ("read a whole chapter", but less than a quarter relevant). Lectures are not thorough.
He is very knoledgable and passinate proffesor.

Takes in late assignments, as well as lenient grading on all assessments. Took accountability for low midterm avg applied a curve. Held 4 hour zoom meetings on the weekend to help students review for final exam. Occasionally funny, even made some jokes on midterm and final. Only gripe was that the organization of the course was messy and confusing.

Morteza's lectures were always very detailed and he clearly cares, always answering questions thoroughly. Grading has many parts (assignments, weekly work, project writeups), but all of these prepare you well for the final, and he grades leniently. We could choose any topic we wanted for the project with a presentation at the end. Highly recommend.

Awesome professor. Morteza is very caring and wants his students to do as well as possible. His workload is a little heavy at times with several assignments due in the latter half of the course but he adjusts assignments and exams slightly when he sees the class generally is struggling.
